page.title: 13LOCAL HISTORY. WATER MILL
page.content: The mill has been unchanged externally since rebuilding shortly after 1858, replacing the earlier, possibly 16th Century, dilapidated mill. The 1858 survey of it refers to the low power of the two open-bucket water-wheels driving 3 pairs of Gray stones, and one pair each of Black stones, French stones and a Shelling stone. There is evidence of a much larger iron water-wheel on the south side. A wooden axle open-bucket wheel on the north side (remains were removed about 1970) provided power for the hammer-mill and rolling-mill, prior to the water-turbine installed in 1910, and which is still in use driving the rolling-mill. The mill which in 1985 employed 3 men, is used as a retail outlet and store for pre-packaged cattle feeds, although locally grown barley is still rolled in the mill.
